00017 package WeBWorK::Utils::FormatRecords;
00018 use base qw(Exporter);
00019 
00020 =head1 NAME
00021 
00022 WeBWorK::Utils::FormatRecords - utilities for formatting database records as
00023 strings.
00024 
00025 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00026 
00027  use WeBWorK::Utils::FormatRecords qw/getFormatsForClass/;
00028  
00029  # get a list of formats
00030  my ($formatsRef, $formatLabelsRef) = getFormatsForClass(ref $Users[0]);
00031  my @formats      = @$formatsRef;      # format names
00032  my %formatLabels = %$formatLabelsRef; # suitable for CGI's "-labels" parameter
00033 
00034  use WeBWorK::Utils::FormatRecords qw/formatRecords/;
00035  
00036  # start with a hash mapping identifiers to records
00037  my %Records = map { $_->user_id => $_ } $db->getUsers($db->listUsers);
00038  
00039  # format the records using a preset
00040  my %recordLabels = formatRecords({preset=>"lnfn_uid"}, %Records);
00041  
00042  # or provide a custom format
00043  my %options = {
00044     field_order   => [ qw/user_id section recitation/ ],
00045     format_string => "%s %s/%s", # suitable for sprintf
00046  };
00047  my %recordLabels = formatRecords(\%options, %Records);
00048  
00049  # %recordLabels is suitable for CGI's "-labels" parameter
00050 
00051 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00052 
00053 This module provides record formatting functions, and a collection of preset
00054 formats for the standard WeBWorK record classes. Formats are specified by a list
00055 of field names and an sprintf format string.
00056 
00057 =cut
00058 
00059 use strict;
00060 use warnings;
00061 use Carp;
00062 use WeBWorK::Utils qw/formatDateTime/;
00063 
00064 our @EXPORT    = ();
00065 our @EXPORT_OK = qw(
00066     getFormatsForClass
00067     formatRecords
00068 );
00069 
00070 use constant PRESET_FORMATS => {
00071     "WeBWorK::DB::Record::User" => {
00072         "uid_lnfn" => {
00073             name => "user_id - last_name, first_name",
00074             field_order => [ qw/user_id last_name first_name/ ],
00075             format_string => "%s - %s, %s",
00076         },
00077         "lnfn_uid" => {
00078             name => "last_name, first_name (user_id)",
00079             field_order => [ qw/last_name first_name user_id/ ],
00080             format_string => "%s, %s (%s)",
00081         },
00082         "lnfn_section" => {
00083             name => "last_name, first_name (section)",
00084             field_order => [ qw/last_name first_name section/ ],
00085             format_string => "%s, %s (%s)",
00086         },
00087         "lnfn_recitation" => {
00088             name => "last_name, first_name (recitation)",
00089             field_order => [ qw/last_name first_name recitation/ ],
00090             format_string => "%s, %s (%s)",
00091         },
00092         "lnfn_secrec" => {
00093             name => "last_name, first_name (section/recitation)",
00094             field_order => [ qw/last_name first_name section recitation/ ],
00095             format_string => "%s, %s (%s/%s)",
00096         },
00097         "lnfn_email" => {
00098             name => "last_name, first_name (email_address)",
00099             field_order => [ qw/last_name first_name email_address/ ],
00100             format_string => "%s, %s (%s)",
00101         },
00102     },
00103     "WeBWorK::DB::Record::Set" => {
00104         "sid" => {
00105             name => "set_id",
00106             field_order => [ qw/set_id/ ],
00107         },
00108         #"sid_open" => {
00109         #   name => "set_id (open_date)",
00110         #   field_order => [ qw/set_id open_date/ ],
00111         #   format_function => sub { sprintf("%s (%s)", $_[0], formatDateTime($_[1])) }
00112         #},
00113         #"sid_due" => {
00114         #   name => "set_id (due_date)",
00115         #   field_order => [ qw/set_id due_date/ ],
00116         #   format_function => sub { sprintf("%s (%s)", $_[0], formatDateTime($_[1])) }
00117         #},
00118         #"sid_answer" => {
00119         #   name => "set_id (answer_date)",
00120         #   field_order => [ qw/set_id answer_date/ ],
00121         #   format_function => sub { sprintf("%s (%s)", $_[0], formatDateTime($_[1])) }
00122         #},
00123     },
00124         "WeBWorK::DB::Record::SetVersion" => {
00125                 "sid" => {
00126                         name => "set_id",
00127                         field_order => [ qw/set_id/ ],
00128                 },
00129         },
00130 };
00131 
00132 =head1 FUNCTIONS
00133 
00134 =over
00135 
00136 =item getFormatsForClass($class)
00137 
00138 Given the name of a record class, returns the preset formats available for that
00139 class.
00140 
00141 The return value consists of a two-element list. The first element is a
00142 reference to a list of format names. The second element is a reference to a hash
00143 mapping format names to string descriptions.
00144 
00145 Together, these two lists are suitable for passing to the C<-values> and
00146 C<-labels> parameters of several CGI module methods, i.e. popup_menu(),
00147 scrolling_list(), checkbox_group(), and radio_group().
00148 
00149 =cut
00150 
00151 sub getFormatsForClass {
00152     my ($class) = @_;
00153     
00154     my %class_presets = exists PRESET_FORMATS->{$class} ? %{ PRESET_FORMATS->{$class} } : ();
00155     
00156     # i don't think we want formats consisting of a single field, so these are disabled
00157     #my @field_order = $class->FIELDS;
00158     my @preset_order = sort { $class_presets{$a}{name} cmp $class_presets{$b}{name} } keys %class_presets;
00159     
00160     #my %fields = map { $_ => "Field: $_" } @field_order;
00161     #my %presets = map { $_ => "Preset: $class_presets{$_}{name}" } @preset_order;
00162     my %presets = map { $_ => $class_presets{$_}{name} } @preset_order;
00163     
00164     #return ( [@field_order, @preset_order], {%fields, %presets} );
00165     return ( \@preset_order, \%presets );
00166 }
00167 
00168 =item formatRecords(\%options, %Records)
00169 
00170 Given a format specification (or the name of a preset format) and a hash mapping
00171 record identifiers to records, returns a hash mapping identifiers to formatted
00172 strings.
00173 
00174 The keys of the %Records hash are not used by formatRecords() They are a
00175 convenience for you.
00176 
00177 %options can consist of:
00178 
00179  preset => the name of a preset format listed by getFormatsForClass()
00180 
00181 or:
00182 
00183  field_order   => a reference to a list of fields in the records' class
00184  format_string => an sprintf format string corresponding to the fields listed above
00185 
00186 or:
00187 
00188  field_order     => a reference to a list of fields in the records' class
00189  format_function => a coderef to which to pass the contents of the fields in field_order
00190 
00191 If C<preset> is given, and its value does not match any known preset but I<is>
00192 the name of a field in the record class, the format is assumed to consist of
00193 that single field.
00194 
00195 If C<format_function> is given, the subroutine referenced is passed to contents
00196 of each field listed in C<field_order>. The subroutine should return a formatted
00197 string.
00198 
00199 The return value is suitable for passing to the C<-labels> parameter of several
00200 CGI module methods, i.e. popup_menu(), scrolling_list(), checkbox_group(), and
00201 radio_group().
00202 
00203 =cut
00204 
00205 sub formatRecords {
00206     my ($options, %Records) = @_;
00207     
00208     # nothing to do
00209     return () unless %Records;
00210     
00211     # get class info (we assume that the records are all of the same type)
00212     my ($tempKey, $tempValue) = each %Records;
00213     my $class = ref $tempValue;
00214     my %class_fields = map { $_ => 1 } $class->FIELDS;
00215     
00216     my %options = %$options;
00217     
00218     if (exists $options{"preset"}) {
00219         my $preset = $options{preset};
00220         
00221         if (exists PRESET_FORMATS->{$class} and exists PRESET_FORMATS->{$class}->{$preset}) {
00222             # an explicit preset exists
00223             # replace the contents of %options with the values from the preset
00224             %options = %{ PRESET_FORMATS->{$class}->{$preset} };
00225         } elsif (exists $class_fields{$preset}) {
00226             # it's the name of a field in the current class, in which case we treat it as
00227             # a "fields" sort with a single field
00228             %options = ( field_order => [ $preset ] );
00229         } else {
00230             croak "preset \"$preset\" not found for class \"$class\"";
00231         }
00232     }
00233     
00234     croak "field_order not found in options list" unless exists $options{field_order};
00235     croak "field_order is not an arrayref" unless ref $options{field_order} eq "ARRAY";
00236     my @field_order = @{ $options{field_order} };
00237     croak "field_order is empty -- no fields to display" unless @field_order;
00238     
00239     my $format_function;
00240     if (exists $options{format_function}) {
00241         croak "format_function is not a coderef" unless ref $options{format_function} eq "CODE";
00242         $format_function = $options{format_function};
00243     }
00244     
00245     # default format_string is "%s %s %s ... %s".
00246     my $format_string = $options{format_string} || "%s " x (@field_order-1) . "%s";
00247     
00248     if ($format_function) {
00249         # if we were passed format_function, call it on each record
00250         foreach my $value (values %Records) {
00251             # $value is initially a record, and is then replaced with a formatted string
00252             $value = $format_function->(map { $value->$_ } @field_order);
00253         }
00254     } else {
00255         # otherwise, use sprintf and format_string
00256         foreach my $value (values %Records) {
00257             # $value is initially a record, and is then replaced with a formatted string
00258             $value = sprintf($format_string, map { $value->$_ } @field_order);
00259         }
00260     }
00261     
00262     return %Records;
00263 }
00264 
00265 =back
00266 
00267 =cut
00268 
00269 =head1 BUGS
00270 
00271 The calling semantics of formatRecords is somewhat inflexible. We shouldn't make
00272 the user pass a hash if a list is sufficient for their use.
00273 
00274 =cut
00275 
00276 1;
